conversation:
Persuader: Hey, how are you doing, have you ever heard of a charity called Save the Children? [Initiate conversation and introduce the topic of a charity]
Persuadee: No I havent. [Respond to the question and indicate lack of knowledge about the charity]
Persuadee: What is it about? [Request more information about the charity]
Persuader: It's an international organization that promotes children's rights, provides relief and helps support children in developing countries, does that sound like something you'd get behind? [Provide information about the charity and gauge interest]
Persuadee: No thank you. [Decline interest in the charity]
Persuader: May I ask why? [Seek reasons for the lack of interest]
Persuader: Your help could really make a difference in a child's life, think of a child who didn't have enough to eat, just a small bit of help may have saved them, are you sure you're not interested? [Attempt to persuade by emphasizing the impact of the help]
Persuadee: I am already making a difference in many children lives. [State current involvement in helping children]
Persuader: That's great, it sounds like it's an issue you really care about then, why not put some of that effort into a charity that's doing really great work like Save the Children? [Acknowledge the effort and suggest contributing to the specific charity]
Persuadee: I have donated 15 years of my life to charity [Highlight past significant contributions to charity]
Persuader: I'm not asking you to donate years of your life, just a couple of cents if possible, is that something you could possibly do tonight? [Clarify the request for a small monetary donation]
Persuadee: No thank you [Decline the request again]
Persuader: You're probably on a computer right now, so you probably have quite a bit of money yourself, don't you think you could spare maybe 25 cents for some needy children around the world? [Attempt to persuade by suggesting the affordability of a small donation]
Persuadee: No thank you [Decline the request again]
Persuader: Do you have children yourself? [Inquire about the personal context (having children)]
Persuader: What if your children were in a position these kids are in, wouldn't you want someone to help them? [Appeal to empathy by comparing the situation to the listener's children]

conversation:
Persuader: Hi there [Greeting the other person]
Persuadee: Hello [Responding to the greeting]
Persuader: Have you heard of the Save the Children charity? [Introducing the topic of the Save the Children charity]
Persuadee: I actually have not. [Expressing lack of knowledge about the charity]
Persuadee: What do they do to help children? [Inquiring about the charity's activities]
Persuader: It is an international organization that helps protect and promote rights for childrens and provides for them in suffering conditions - such as lack of basic needs, like water, clothing, and food. [Providing information about the charity's mission and activities]
Persuadee: I'm glad a charity like that exists internationally. [Expressing approval of the charity's existence]
Persuader: It's for a great cause. [Affirming the value of the charity's cause]
Persuader: Children are the future and unfortunately too many of them don't get the quality of life that we take advantage of today. [Emphasizing the importance of helping children]
Persuader: Sometimes we're in a better place and we have to do what we can to help their conditions a little bit. [Encouraging the idea of helping those in need]
Persuader: Even little bits can go a long way, you know? [Highlighting that small contributions can make a difference]
Persuadee: it does, and charities can go further with the amount of money donated. [Agreeing and noting the impact of donations]
Persuader: Absolutely. [Agreeing with the previous statement]
Persuader: I remember seeing ads on the television about it and it breaks my hear to see children so sad and suffering in conditions that they live in. [Sharing a personal reaction to seeing ads about the charity]
Persuader: I haven't personally witnessed experiences first hand, however, it comes down to basic human needs. [Clarifying that their understanding is based on general knowledge]
Persuadee: It's sad to think being born in the wrong conditions can have such a lifelong impact. [Expressing sadness about the impact of being born in poor conditions]
Persuader: Exactly. [Agreeing with the sentiment expressed]
Persuader: It's not like we really get the choice of how/when/where we are born. [Reflecting on the randomness of birth conditions]
Persuader: It's a matter of chance. [Reiterating the idea of chance in birth conditions]
Persuader: It's unfair to be born into conditions like that. [Expressing the unfairness of being born into poor conditions]
Persuadee: Hopefully, more the people born more lucky can lend a hand. [Hoping that more fortunate people will help]

conversation:
Persuader: It would be really helpful if you donated to Save the Children fund! [Requesting a donation to Save the Children fund]
Persuadee: What does the money go towards if I donate? [Inquiring about the allocation of donated money]
Persuader: When crisis strikes and children are most vulnerable, we are always among the first to respond and the last to leave. [Explaining the organization's response during crises]
Persuader: We ensure children's unique needs are met and their voices are heard. [Emphasizing the focus on children's needs and voices]
Persuader: We deliver lasting results for millions of children, including those hardest to reach. [Highlighting the impact and reach of their efforts]
Persuader: We do whatever it takes for children ??Â¸??Â¸ transforming their lives and the future we share ??Â¸??Â¸ because we believe every child deserves a future. [Reinforcing the organization's commitment to children's futures]
Persuadee: Where in the world are the children located? [Asking about the geographical locations of the children helped]
Persuader: US and global, wherever children need help, they are there. [Clarifying that help is provided both in the US and globally]
Persuadee: If I donate $25, does that go a long way? [Questioning the impact of a $25 donation]
Persuader: Absolutely, a small amount of money for us turns out to be life changing for those in need. [Assuring that even small donations are impactful]
Persuader: A dollar can buy a lot! [Emphasizing the value of a dollar in their programs]
Persuadee: Will it help towards education? [Inquiring if donations support education]
Persuader: Yes, it is one of the core programs. [Confirming that education is a core program]
Persuader: It leads children out of poverty so is a large focus. [Explaining the importance of education in alleviating poverty]
Persuadee: Do you accept monthly donations of smaller amounts? [Asking about the possibility of monthly donations]
Persuader: You can do a one time donation or a monthly subscription. [Informing about one-time and monthly donation options]

conversation:
Persuader: Hello [Greeting the other person]
Persuadee: Yea, hello. [Acknowledging the greeting]
Persuadee: Glad you took your time. [Expressing sarcasm or frustration]
Persuader: I'd like to speak to you about Save the Children. [Introducing the topic of conversation]
Persuader: Do you have any kids? [Inquiring about the other person's personal life]
Persuadee: No, I do not have kids. [Responding to the inquiry]
Persuadee: What is Save the Children about? [Asking for more information about the topic]
Persuader: Save the Children is an international non-governemnt organization. [Providing basic information about the organization]
Persuader: Their goal is to promotes children's rights, provides relief and helps support children in developing countries. [Explaining the goals and activities of the organization]
Persuadee: That sounds really cool. [Expressing interest or approval]
Persuadee: What specific countries do they help out? [Asking for specific details]
Persuader: They help out many third world countries from all over the world. [Providing additional information]
Persuadee: Okay. [Acknowledging the information]
Persuadee: I guess I would look them up sometime to find out more. [Expressing intent to research further]
Persuader: How do you feel about those who were unluckily born to poor circumstances? [Inquiring about the other person's feelings on a related issue]
Persuadee: I feel like it's a shame and I wish we could do more. [Expressing empathy and concern]
Persuadee: How can I help? [Asking how they can contribute or help]
Persuader: You sound like a really kind person. [Complimenting the other person]
Persuader: Would you like to make a donation to Save the Children. [Requesting a donation]
Persuader: Anything will help. [Encouraging any level of contribution]
Persuadee: Thank you, I would like to make a 50 dollar donation but first. [Expressing willingness to donate and asking for more information]
Persuadee: Is there a website for this charity? [Inquiring about the charity's website]
Persuader: Thank you! [Expressing gratitude]

conversation:
Persuader: Hello! [Greeting the other person]
Persuader: How're you doing today? [Inquiring about the other person's well-being]
Persuadee: Hey, kind of tired but overall good. [Responding to the inquiry and sharing personal state]
Persuadee: How are you? [Returning the inquiry about well-being]
Persuader: I'm doing alright. [Responding to the inquiry about well-being]
Persuader: I just had a thought on my mind that I wanted to ask you about [Introducing a topic they want to discuss]
Persuadee: Yea? [Expressing interest and prompting to continue]
Persuadee: Go for it. [Encouraging the other person to proceed with their topic]
Persuader: Do you donate when you get the chance? [Asking a question about the other person's donation habits]
Persuader: I was thinking about how everywhere you go, they ask you to donate .50 here and your change there. [Providing context and elaborating on the topic of donations]
Persuader: I think I need to actually start donating. [Expressing a personal intention to start donating]
Persuader: How does it make you feel? [Asking for the other person's feelings on the topic]
Persuader: Do you donate? [Reiterating the question about donation habits]
Persuadee: I don't like to donate to for profit businesses. [Expressing a personal stance on donating to for-profit businesses]
Persuadee: I feel like they'll just take my donation and get their tax credit. [Explaining the reasoning behind their stance]
Persuader: How do you feel about Save the Children? [Asking for the other person's opinion on a specific charity]
Persuader: My nephew had to get taken into the hospital not too long ago and I just got the letter in the mail saying they used Save the Childrens donation money to help him. [Sharing a personal story related to the charity]
Persuader: I'm thinking about donating to them. [Expressing an intention to donate to the charity]
Persuadee: I'm sorry to hear about your nephew? [Expressing sympathy for the situation]
Persuadee: What happened, if you don't mind me asking. [Inquiring further about the situation]
Persuader: We found out the hard way that he has actual celiacs (sorry I can't spell too well) and he has an allergic reaction to the cake on his birthday. [Explaining the medical condition and incident involving their nephew]
Persuader: He went through a TON of testing and that's how they caught it. [Providing additional details about the medical testing]
Persuader: He has to stay overnight at the hospital for a few weeks and his parents just couldn't afford it. [Describing the financial difficulty faced by the family]
Persuader: That's when Save the Children came around to help [Explaining how the charity helped in the situation]
Persuadee: Oh my gosh. [Expressing shock and sympathy]
Persuadee: I am so sorry to hear about the little guy and how his birthday, too. [Expressing further sympathy and concern]
Persuadee: How did Save the Children help? [Inquiring about the specific help provided by the charity]
Persuader: They helped cover the bills for it since he's in Africa. [Explaining the specific assistance provided by the charity]
Persuader: He's doing much better now though! [Providing an update on the nephew's current condition]
Persuadee: Oh wow. [Expressing surprise]
Persuadee: All the way in Africa. [Commenting on the geographical distance]
Persuadee: I'm really glad to hear that. [Expressing happiness for the positive outcome]

conversation:

Persuader: Instead of the typical charities that help children in a far away land, we here use state of the art location technology to help children in need right in your own community so you can see your money at work personally [Explaining the unique approach of the charity]
Persuadee: What would my money do exactly [Requesting specific information about the use of donations]
Persuader: It would go to the three most important things that a child need. [Providing information about the allocation of donations]
Persuader: Food, shelter, and education. [Listing the primary needs addressed by the charity]

conversation:
Persuader: Hey, good to be chatting with you tonight. [Initiate conversation]

Persuader: Do you have a moment? [Seek confirmation of availability]
Persuadee: Yes, I do [Confirm availability]
Persuader: I'd like to talk about children. [Specify topic of discussion]

Persuader: Have you heard of the Save The Children Foundation? [To introduce the topic of the Save The Children Foundation]

Persuader: How much would you be willing to donate to Save the Children? [To inquire about the EE's willingness to donate to Save the Children]

conversation:
Persuader: Hi there. [Greeting the other person]
Persuader: How are you today? [Inquiring about the other person's well-being]
Persuadee: Hello, I am fine, how about you? [Responding to the greeting and inquiring back]
Persuader: Very well thanks. [Responding positively to the inquiry]
Persuader: Do you currently give any money to charity on a regular basis? [Inquiring about the other person's charitable activities]
Persuadee: Yes, I try to help time to time [Confirming participation in charitable activities]
Persuader: Any charity in particular? [Asking for specifics about the charities supported]
Persuadee: No, anything that catches my eyes, or I find them on gofundme, what about you? [Explaining the approach to choosing charities and inquiring about the other person's activities]
Persuader: I have a few payments set up monthly. [Sharing personal charitable activities]
Persuader: I assume then you've heard of Save the Children and the great work they do with young people? [Introducing a specific charity (Save the Children)]
Persuadee: Yes, I've heard of it. [Confirming awareness of the charity]
Persuadee: Can you please explain more about it? [Requesting more information about the charity]
Persuader: Firstly, they provide funds and support services to help protect vulnerable children all over the world. [Providing information about the charity's activities]
Persuader: Once the children have a safe environment the next priority is to improve their lives via education and other resources. [Continuing to provide information about the charity's priorities]
Persuader: They really make a difference to the lives of children in poverty or destitution. [Emphasizing the impact of the charity's work]
Persuadee: I am interested in it. [Expressing interest in the charity]
Persuadee: I already checked their website. [Indicating prior research on the charity]
Persuadee: Health and education both are important factors [Stating the importance of health and education]
Persuader: Absolutely. [Agreeing with the importance of health and education]
Persuader: And the great thing for us is that even a very small donation goes a long way due to the number of people who can donate! [Highlighting the impact of small donations]
Persuader: We're asking people today to give a small part of the payment for this HIT to the charity. [Requesting a small donation from the other person]
Persuader: You'll get a box pop up at teh end of our chat which will give you the opportunity to donate something. [Informing about the donation process at the end of the chat]
Persuader: Obviously the more the better, but I also appreciate that you aren't turking for free so you can judge it yourself. [Encouraging a larger donation but acknowledging the other person's financial situation]
Persuadee: Actually I like these kind of HITs. [Expressing a positive attitude towards donation-based HITs]
Persuadee: I did few HITs before that asked me to donate my bonus or half of the reward. [Sharing past experiences with similar HITs]
Persuadee: I happily did. [Expressing willingness to donate]
Persuadee: I am sure there are people who need it more than me [Recognizing the needs of others]
Persuader: You're absolutely right-  sometimes we don't realise it, but what seems like a little bit of moeny to us can make a big difference to them. [Agreeing and emphasizing the impact of small donations]
Persuader: I worked in Africa earlier this year and the difference a few dollars can make to people over there is unbelievable. [Sharing personal experience to illustrate the impact of donations]
Persuadee: Yes, few dollars can save a child or can help a family to survive for a month. [Agreeing and emphasizing the impact of small donations]
Persuadee: How long have you worked there? [Inquiring about the duration of the other person's work in Africa]

conversation:
Persuader: Hello! How are you doing today? [Greeting and initiating conversation]
Persuadee: I'm doing very well thank you! [Responding positively to greeting]
Persuadee: How is your day going so far? [Inquiring about the other person's well-being]
Persuader: I am doing well. [Responding to inquiry about well-being]
Persuader: My day has been busy visiting different places to speak about the charity I support. [Providing information about their day and charity work]
Persuader: Have you heard of Save the Children? [Introducing the charity "Save the Children"]
Persuadee: It sounds familiar to me, could you tell me more about it? [Expressing familiarity and requesting more information]
Persuader: Helping children in countries that are very war torn or in some form of conflict is what we help in. [Explaining the charity's mission]
Persuader: Everyday 16,000 children die before their 5th birthday, 1 out of 80 flee the country and risk everything, and 1 out of 6 kids aren't enrolled in a school or getting education that they need [Providing statistics to emphasize the charity's importance]
Persuadee: The charity sounds like it is doing some good work in an area that badly needs it. [Acknowledging the charity's good work]
Persuadee: Children should be our top priority all across the world. [Expressing a belief in the importance of children's welfare]
Persuadee: How can someone get involved and help out with this charity? [Inquiring about ways to get involved with the charity]
Persuader: Oh there are quiet a few ways. [Indicating there are multiple ways to help]
Persuader: For roughly a dollar a day you can sponsor a child, you can choose a gift to spend to a child through our catalog, you could start a fundraiser, or you can just simply donate. [Listing specific ways to support the charity]
Persuader: With that, keep in mind if you ever decide to make a monetary donation, 86% goes directly to the children, 9% fundraising, and 5% management and general. [Providing details about the allocation of donations]
Persuader: Just so you can have an idea that we use 9 out of 10 dollars directly on the children. [Reinforcing the efficient use of donations]
Persuadee: I do believe I would like to donate some money to the Save the Children charity. [Expressing a desire to donate]
Persuadee: Could I pledge $1/day to start with? [Specifying the amount they wish to donate]
Persuader: absolutely thank you so much!! [Expressing gratitude for the donation]
Persuadee: I like to donate money and time to charities that help children so I also want to thank you for educating me on this charity! [Expressing appreciation for the information and their own commitment to helping children]
Persuader: Absolutely. [Affirming the previous statement]
Persuader: I love getting the word out there on this charity. [Expressing passion for spreading awareness about the charity]
Persuader: I strongly believe in it and its values on helping children. [Sharing personal belief in the charity's values]
Persuader: Children should be a priority in the world. [Reiterating the importance of children]
Persuader: They are our future. [Emphasizing the future importance of children]
Persuadee: They are our future exactly. [Agreeing with the importance of children]
Persuadee: Any time I can help improve a situation for a child in need I hope to be able to do so. [Expressing a personal commitment to helping children]
Persuadee: How long have you been supporting this charity? [Inquiring about the speaker's history with the charity]

Persuadee: It sucks that not all people and children have the comfort of having a stable place to stay or the comfort of knowing they are able to eat. [Express empathy and concern]
Persuadee: It is sad. [Reiterate sadness]

Persuadee: I did not have to worry about those things. [Provide personal background information]

Persuader: I felt safe and secure in my home. [Share personal experience]
Persuader: That is absolutely wonderful. [Express positive reaction to EE's background]
Persuader: I feel many people take that for granted. [Comment on common attitudes]
Persuader: Not having to worry about those things while growing up. [Reiterate previous statement]
Persuadee: It is not a problem just for children. [Expand the scope of the problem]
Persuadee: There are many homeless adults and adolescents that do not know where their next meal is coming from, or if it will ever arrive. [Provide additional context and examples]
Persuader: It would be great if we could work together to assure that everyone have at least those basic necessities met. [Propose collaboration to address the issue]

Persuader: Save the Children makes sure to give as much as they possibly can, because they understand that when it comes to people who are starving, every penny counts. [Emphasize the organization's commitment to maximizing aid]
Persuadee: Is there any concrete proof that they do? [Request concrete evidence of the organization's claims]
Persuadee: Words are just words sometimes. [Express doubt about verbal assurances]

Persuadee: I was not aware of that fact, no. [Confirm lack of awareness about the statistic]

Persuader: We're talking about children in need. [Emphasize the focus on children in need]
Persuader: Dying, when the world knows how to save them. [Stress the preventable nature of child deaths]
Persuader: Vulnerable children in poverty. [Highlight the vulnerability of children in poverty]
Persuader: Denied an education. [Point out the denial of education to children]
Persuader: Forced to flee violence. [Mention children forced to flee violence]
Persuader: Orphaned, abused, abandoned. [List other hardships faced by children]
Persuader: Children with no reason to smile. [Describe the emotional state of affected children]
Persuader: No hope for the future. [Emphasize the lack of hope for the future among children]

Persuadee: I'm guessing a lot more than me. [Express suspicion about the CEO's salary being high]
Persuader: I can certainly understand where you are coming from, and family does come first. [Acknowledge the donor's perspective and prioritize family]

conversation:
Persuader: Hello. [Greeting the other person.]
Persuader: I have a story to share with you. [Introducing the purpose of the conversation.]
Persuadee: Of course im hear to listen . [Expressing willingness to listen.]
Persuader: I just donated to Save the Children and feel like it will be super helpful. [Sharing a recent charitable action.]
Persuader: There was a child who died of hunger and I think my donation will help other children. [Providing context and reasoning for the donation.]
Persuadee: Yes i believe it most DEFINETLY will make a big impact on others lives and its amazing to see such kind hearted people like yourself do so. [Affirming the positive impact of the donation and complimenting the speaker.]
Persuader: Thanks! [Expressing gratitude.]
Persuader: I just read that The United Nations estimated last year 25,000 people still die of hunger daily. [Sharing a fact to emphasize the severity of the issue.]
Persuader: That means more than 9.1 million people die of hunger every year. [Providing additional context to highlight the problem.]
Persuadee: Yes its such a sad thing to see happen myself and family are very kind hearted and feel for all the people around the world who are suffering from this , And would love to make a change and to help . [Expressing empathy and a desire to help.]
Persuader: Great to hear there are still kind hearted people to help people suffering! [Expressing appreciation for others' kindness.]
Persuader: It makes me angry to know of so many children in danger in the world. [Expressing frustration about the issue.]
Persuadee: Yes its so sad how people can go about their day and not think of those who are in great need ! [Agreeing and expressing sadness about the situation.]
Persuadee: Especially those who are very wealthy themselves and don't care to make a difference [Criticizing wealthy individuals who do not help.]
Persuader: I agree! [Agreeing with the previous statement.]
Persuader: I certainly am not wealthy but still try to make donation as often as I can. [Sharing personal financial status and commitment to donating.]
Persuader: There are some wealthy people that are great philanthropists, but I think more people like you and I are needed to make even small donations. [Emphasizing the importance of small donations from many people.]
Persuader: Have you ever been to the Save the Children website?  URL [Inquiring if the other person is familiar with the charity.]
Persuadee: Yes most definitely i totally agree with you! [Agreeing with the previous statement.]
Persuadee: Yes i do i actually watch a family on youtube that raises money every year live streaming for save the children and all the money they receive goes to save the children [Sharing personal experience related to the charity.]
Persuader: You can make a donation from your incoming earning from this task to Save the Children. [Suggesting a way to donate.]
Persuader: Even just a small amount makes a difference? [Encouraging even small donations.]
Persuader: I just realized I sound like a telemarketer! [Self-reflecting on the tone of the conversation.]
Persuader: Can you donate part of your payment? [Directly asking for a donation.]
Persuader: I think we should. [Expressing a collective responsibility to donate.]
Persuadee: As of right now i honestly would but i dont have the funds for it if their are other ways im albe to get others to donate as well and help out in any way possible i will be more then willing to do so.. [Explaining current financial constraints and willingness to help in other ways.]
Persuader: Even just a small donation helps. [Reiterating the value of small donations.]
Persuader: I will donate again if you match the amount of a snack! [Proposing a matching donation challenge.]
Persuader: Maybe .50 perhaps? [Suggesting a specific small donation amount.]
Persuadee: of course i could do so from my paypal [Agreeing to make a donation.]
Persuader: The research team will collect donations and send it to Save the Children. [Explaining the donation process.]
Persuader: So we don't even need to use Paypal. [Clarifying that PayPal is not needed.]
Persuadee: oh okay then thats awsome to hear [Expressing approval of the donation process.]
Persuader: Ok great! [Expressing satisfaction with the agreement.]

conversation:
Persuader: Hello, how are you today. [Greeting and initiating conversation]
Persuadee: Very well, thank you. [Responding to greeting]
Persuadee: And you? [Inquiring about the other person's well-being]
Persuader: I'm great, thank you. [Responding to inquiry and expressing well-being]
Persuader: I'm wondering if I can have a moment of your time to talk to you about a charity program I work with? [Requesting time to discuss a charity program]
Persuadee: Sure. [Agreeing to listen]
Persuadee: Go right ahead. [Encouraging the speaker to proceed]
Persuader: Thank you. [Expressing gratitude]
Persuader: I'm hoping you would like to donate some of your task payment to the charity 'Save the Children', and organization that promotes children's rights and supports children in developing countries. [Requesting a donation and providing information about the charity]
Persuadee: I would be interested in doing do, however I must tell you I am generally very skeptical about charity orginizations in general. [Expressing interest but also skepticism about charities]
Persuadee: I know of many that I do not support due to the 6 figure salaries of the CEO. [Providing reasons for skepticism]
Persuadee: And the fact that not much of the donation actually get to the "cause". [Further elaborating on reasons for skepticism]
Persuader: I completely understand the skepticism due to a tenfold of shady organizations these days. [Acknowledging and understanding the skepticism]
Persuader: However, I can guarantee you Save the Children is a professional organization that promises their donations go to a trustable fund to support international children's causes. [Assuring the credibility of the charity]
Persuadee: You have my attention, however this HIT is running Very long for 2 bucks already. [Expressing interest but concern about the time spent]
Persuader: So can I conclude that you'd like to donate to the charity now? [Seeking confirmation for the donation]
Persuader: Your donation will be directly deducted from your task payment. [Explaining the donation process]
Persuadee: No, you may not draw that conclusion yet. [Declining to confirm the donation]
Persuadee: I still know nothing about the charity and I\'m already a half hour into a 2 dollar HIT. [Expressing frustration about the time spent and lack of information]
Persuadee: I do not do this "only" for the money, but to try and help any way I can. [Explaining motivation beyond monetary gain]
Persuadee: That\'s the only reason I\'m still here. [Reiterating motivation for staying in the conversation]
Persuader: I can understand that. [Expressing understanding]
Persuader: So i'd really like to thank you for your interest and time. [Thanking for interest and time]
Persuader: I can assure you if you donate as little as a penny to this charity you can be part of the solution to put an end to children's struggles from all over the world. [Encouraging even a small donation and emphasizing its impact]
Persuadee: I have been doing some research while waiting for your responses. [Indicating independent research on the charity]
Persuadee: I'll donate .50. [Agreeing to make a small donation]

Persuadee: 30 dollars a month can change a child's life [Provide specific information about donation impact]
Persuader: Yeah I know this great charity called Save the Children that takes money for this exact type of issue. [Recommend a specific charity]
Persuader: We should donate to them! [Encourage action]
Persuadee: I know! [Express agreement]
Persuadee: What a worthwhile cause! [Affirm the value of the cause]
Persuader: They also have a website  URL if you would like to look it up and make sure it's a legit organization [Provide additional information for verification]
Persuadee: Yeah, I have used Gospel for Asia in the past [Share past experience with a different charity]
Persuader: I think we should use Save the Children this time for a more global effort though [Advocate for a specific charity for broader impact]
Persuadee: It feels good to make a difference if only for one child [Express positive feelings about making a difference]
Persuader: This is true. [Agree with EE's sentiment]

Persuader: Save the Children also a great and very professional organization. [Reiterate the quality of Save the Children]
Persuader: They are credentialed internationally and have a great reputation for using their money wisely. [Highlight the organization's credentials and reputation]

conversation:
Persuader: Have you thought about how much of the reward for this HIT you want to donate to Save the Children? [Inquire about willingness to donate]

Persuadee: I know that it is a good organization and I support them. [Acknowledge charity's value]

Persuadee: I want the money to do with as I choose. [Assert control over reward usage]
Persuader: Save the Children has helped build hundreds of schools in developing nations around the world. [Provide additional information about charity's impact]
Persuader: They've educated many children who have gone on to do important medical and other life saving jobs. [Emphasize charity's success stories]
Persuadee: I still do not want to make a donation from this money. [Reiterate refusal to donate]

Persuadee: I use it for things that my family needs. [Emphasize family needs]

Persuader: Your family is rich enough to live in a first world country and have food on a daily basis. [Imply relative affluence]

Persuadee: I wish this wasn't true. [Expressing a wish that the situation were different.]
Persuader: Seriously. [Affirming the previous statement.]
Persuader: Adults often can't fend for themselves when there's a crisis, but children are especially vulnerable. [Highlighting the particular vulnerability of children in crises.]
Persuader: Do you think that if you could do something to help Syrian children or children in Indonesia, which just experienced an earthquake, you would?. [Asking if the other person would be willing to help children in crisis situations.]
Persuadee: That would be something I would do, yes. [Expressing willingness to help.]
Persuader: Yeah, me too. [Expressing agreement and shared sentiment.]
Persuader: Every day I watch the news and hear about victims all over the world and feel kind of powerless. [Sharing personal feelings of powerlessness in the face of global issues.]
Persuadee: You have more power than you realize. [Encouraging the other person by suggesting they have more power than they realize.]
Persuader: Can you elaborate. [Requesting further explanation.]
Persuader: How do you think people like us could help? [Asking for specific ideas on how people can help.]
Persuadee: We could either donate money or our time. [Suggesting ways to help  such as donating money or time.]
Persuader: Absolutely. [Agreeing with the suggestions.]

Persuader: All of the money they collect goes straight to helping children in war torn parts of the world and places that have suffered natural disasters. [Providing information about the charity's focus and use of funds.]
Persuadee: I will have to take a look at the website. [Expressing intent to research the charity further.]

conversation:
Persuader: Save the Children is a great organization that looks out for the well being of children in need. [Introduce the organization and its mission]
Persuader: Currently they are looking for individuals to help their cause. [Inform about the need for volunteers]
Persuadee: where is this organization based? [Inquire about the organization's location]
Persuadee: Do they help children from a particular country or is it all around the world? [Clarify the scope of the organization's aid]
Persuader: They help children mostly in developing countries around the world. [Provide information on the geographical focus of the aid]
Persuader: Think about all the stories you hear in the news and on social media about children that need help or have been taken advantage of. [Encourage empathy by referencing common stories]
Persuadee: Yeah stories like that are very heart breaking. [Express emotional response to the stories]
Persuadee: What types of programs do they offer? [Inquire about the types of programs offered]
Persuadee: Like do they just supply food? [Seek specific details about the aid provided]
Persuader: They often protect children from being victims of hunger, violence, and child labor. [Describe the protection programs offered]
Persuader: They also advocate for schooling and provide opportunities for families to get ahead. [Highlight additional programs and advocacy efforts]
Persuader: It is a great social cause that is worth donating to! [Encourage donation by emphasizing the cause's worth]
Persuadee: That sound great but you know my biggest concern with making donations to charities is always the question of just how much of the money I give actually reaches to the intended people. [Express concern about the effectiveness of donations]
Persuader: Save the Children is a very well known, credible organization with transparency. [Reassure about the organization's credibility and transparency]
Persuader: Visiting the organization's website allows you to understand how even a small donation can have an impact. [Encourage visiting the website for more information]
Persuadee: Oh I see so they have a website that I could learn more about them. [Acknowledge the availability of the website for further learning]
Persuader: Think about how much money you spend on non essentials in your life. [Prompt reflection on personal spending habits]
Persuader: Now think about sacrificing just one of those to help out a child. [Suggest sacrificing non-essentials for donations]
Persuadee: Yeah I think its good to help any little bit you can. [Agree with the idea of helping in any capacity]
Persuadee: How much is the typical donation amount usually? [Inquire about typical donation amounts]
Persuader: It all depends on what you are comfortable with. [Emphasize that any amount is acceptable]
Persuader: Every bit helps. [Reiterate that every contribution helps]
Persuader: But one thing is for certain, you will feel good about your donation! [Assure that donating will bring personal satisfaction]
Persuadee: So after making a donation, I won't exactly see how the money I give will be used right? [Seek clarification on the visibility of donation impact]
Persuadee: I mean this is not like sponsoring a child or family situation right? [Clarify understanding of the donation process]
Persuader: You will not see how it directly impacts one child, but instead think about focusing on how your donation would impact multiple children and families! [Encourage focusing on the broader impact of donations]

conversation:
Persuader: Hi, how are you today? [Initiate conversation and establish rapport]
Persuadee: okay..and how are you [Respond to greeting and reciprocate inquiry]
Persuader: I'm doing great. [Provide a positive personal update]
Persuader: Out of curiousity, have you heard of the organization Save the Children? [Introduce the topic of Save the Children]
Persuadee: yes..i am very familiar.. [Express familiarity with the organization]
Persuadee: are you involved with charity [Inquire about ER's involvement with charity]
Persuader: Yes! [Confirm involvement with charity]
Persuader: I really prefer local charities but some nationwide and international ones are very dear to my heart. [Share personal preference for local and some international charities]
Persuader: Whenever we have the opportunity to donate from our task rewards I always try to give a little bit. [Explain personal donation habits]
Persuadee: me too..i see many commercials for charity on TV and it breaks my heart.. [Express empathy and shared sentiment towards charity]
Persuadee: i am also a follower of Unicef, are you familiar [Share personal involvement with Unicef and inquire about ER's familiarity]
Persuader: Yes, I've heard of Unicef. [Confirm familiarity with Unicef]
Persuader: Another great organization. [Express positive opinion about Unicef]
Persuader: One thing I love about Save the Children is that they have very high ratings from third-party reportings. [Highlight a positive aspect of Save the Children]
Persuader: I know when I donate to them that my money is being used wisely! [Express trust in the organization's use of donations]
Persuadee: interesting, what do the ratings represent [Seek clarification about the ratings mentioned]
Persuader: The ratings are from different companies such as Better Business Bureau and American Institute of Philanthropy. [Provide information about the sources of the ratings]
Persuader: They actually get the financial reports from the IRS to confirm the accuracy in where the funds are going. [Explain the process of verifying financial reports]
Persuadee: very good...are you interested in other charities involved with children [Inquire about ER's interest in other children's charities]
Persuader: I have given to other organizations in the past, such as World Vision, but Save the Children is really important to me right now. [Share past donations to other organizations and current focus on Save the Children]
Persuader: There is such a lack of support right now in developing countries, and Save the Children really focuses on that. [Explain the importance of Save the Children's focus on developing countries]
Persuadee: i happen to favor unicef since my kids collect for halloween and kids count monies as part of class project. [Share personal preference for Unicef and related activities]
Persuader: I totally understand that. [Acknowledge and validate EE's preference]
Persuader: One thing I like about Save the Children is that it isn't just global but also focuses on kids in need here in the USA, especially the poverty-torn cities. [Highlight another positive aspect of Save the Children]
Persuadee: i tend to give up to 100$ a month to children's org- what is your prefered donation? [Share personal donation habits and inquire about ER's preferred donation amount]

conversation:
Persuader: Have you heard of the Save the Children non profit organization? [To introduce the topic of the Save the Children organization]
Persuadee: Hello, yes I have but I am not sure what the charity works towards [To acknowledge familiarity with the organization and express uncertainty about its mission]
Persuader: It is an international non-governmental organization that promotes children's rights, provides relief and helps support children in developing countries. [To provide information about the organization's mission and activities]
Persuadee: Ah ok very nice. [To express understanding and approval]
Persuadee: It sounds like a good charity. [To express a positive opinion about the charity]
Persuadee: Are you thinking of donating to it? [To inquire about ER's intentions regarding donating to the charity]
Persuader: I am thinking about it. [To express personal consideration of donating]
Persuader: I was hoping you would think about it too. [To encourage EE to consider donating as well]
Persuader: It just sucks that millions of Syrian children have grown up facing the daily threat of violence. [To highlight the plight of Syrian children to evoke empathy]
Persuader: In the first two months of 2018 alone, 1,000 children were reportedly killed or injured in intensifying violence. [To provide a specific statistic to emphasize the severity of the situation]
Persuader: This makes me angry and was wondering if it did the same for you? [To express personal emotional response and seek EE's emotional response]
Persuadee: Yes, I definitely understand you. [To express empathy and understanding]
Persuadee: It is very difficult to see on the news what is happening in Syria and the violence and terrorism that is going on in the country [To elaborate on the emotional difficulty of witnessing the situation in Syria]
Persuader: I know it is crazy. [To agree and express disbelief]
Persuader: Sometimes I think about the little things I buy. [To reflect on personal spending habits]
Persuader: Like yesterday I had a craving for candy so I bought a bag of smarties for $2.79. [To provide a specific example of personal spending]
Persuader: Sometimes I wonder how much it could help someone else instead of just satisfying my cravings. [To express contemplation about the impact of personal spending versus helping others]
Persuadee: Yes that is very true. [To agree with ER's reflection]
Persuadee: I usually donate $1.00 or $2.00 at restaurants or stores whenever they ask me if I would like to donate. [To share personal habit of donating small amounts]
Persuadee: I think it is the least I could do. [To express a sense of duty in donating]
Persuader: That is nice. [To acknowledge and appreciate EE's habit]
Persuader: I try to do the same if I have the extra money. [To share a similar habit when financially able]
Persuader: Usually it is not something I am a strong believer in though. [To express a general lack of strong belief in casual donations]
Persuader: I really like helping others that in third world countries that have no idea what wealth is. [To express a preference for helping those in extreme poverty]
Persuadee: Yes I understand. [To express understanding and agreement]
Persuadee: I have been to third world countries in South America and seeing the living conditions of some people is very tough. [To share personal experience of witnessing poverty in third world countries]
Persuadee: The poverty there is a lot higher than what we are used to seeing and it can be shocking. [To describe the shocking nature of poverty in those regions]
Persuader: I have only been to Mexico and that was an eye opener. [To share a personal experience of witnessing poverty in Mexico]
Persuader: One dollar is so valuable to them. [To emphasize the value of a small amount of money in impoverished areas]
Persuader: It is crazy! [To express amazement at the disparity in value]
Persuadee: Yes I know. [To agree and acknowledge the statement]
Persuadee: Any amount of money can help. [To affirm that any amount of money can be helpful]
Persuadee: I think that we take many things for granted such as running water, and always having food on the table. [To reflect on taking basic necessities for granted]
Persuader: Right! [To agree with EE's reflection]

conversation:
Persuader: Hello, are you interested in protection of rights of children? [Initiate conversation and gauge interest in children's rights protection]
Persuadee: Yes, definitely. [Express interest and agreement]
Persuadee: What do you have in mind? [Seek more information]
Persuader: There is organisation called Save the Children and donations are essential to ensure children's rights to health,education and safety. [Provide information about the organization and its purpose]
Persuadee: Is this the same group where people used to "sponsor" a child? [Clarify understanding and seek confirmation]
Persuader: Here is their website, URL [Provide a resource for further information]
Persuader: They help children all around the world. [Highlight the organization's global impact]
Persuader: For instance, millions of Syrian children have grown up facing the daily threat of violence. [Provide a specific example to illustrate the organization's work]
Persuader: In the first two months of 2018 alone, 1,000 children were reportedly killed or injured in intensifying violence. [Emphasize the urgency and severity of the situation]
Persuadee: I can't imagine how terrible it must be for a child to grow up inside a war zone. [Express empathy and understanding]
Persuader: As you mentioned,this organisation has different programs,and one of them is to "sponsor" child. [Confirm the organization's programs and address the previous question]
Persuader: You choose the location. [Provide additional detail about the program]
Persuadee: Are you connected with the NGO yourself? [Inquire about the speaker's personal connection to the NGO]
Persuader: No,but i want to donate some amount from this survey. [Clarify personal involvement and intention to donate]
Persuader: Research team will send money to this organisation. [Explain the process of donation through the survey]
Persuadee: That sounds great. [Express approval and support]
Persuadee: Does it come from our reward/bonuses? [Seek clarification on the source of the donation funds]
Persuader: Yes,the amount you want to donate is deducted from your reward. [Confirm the donation process and source of funds]

conversation:
Persuader: Hello how are  you doing today? [Initiate conversation and establish rapport]
Persuadee: I'm good, how are you? [Respond to greeting and reciprocate inquiry]
Persuader: I am well. [Respond to inquiry and maintain rapport]
Persuader: Just enjoying the sunny day and trying to help out a charity I am working on, Save the Children. [Share personal activity and introduce charity topic]
Persuadee: I wish I had some sun. [Express personal sentiment and engage in conversation]
Persuadee: Please tell me more about this charity [Show interest and request more information about the charity]
Persuader: This charity is n international non-governmental organization that promotes children's rights, provides relief and helps support children in developing countries. [Provide detailed information about the charity]
Persuader: I have recently donated some money to it. [Share personal involvement to build credibility]
Persuader: Would you be interested in how much I donated? [Engage interest by offering more personal information]
Persuadee: Yes please. [Express interest and request specific information]
Persuadee: And also, was the donation mandatory or voluntary? [Seek clarification on the nature of the donation]
Persuader: I donate about $15 a month and it is all voluntary. [Provide specific details about personal donation and its voluntary nature]
Persuader: I rather put my money into this charity then church offering because I know it directly helps children. [Explain personal preference and rationale for donating to the charity]
Persuader: Would you like to know how I know it helps? [Offer additional information to support the charity's impact]
Persuadee: That sounds like a reasonable amount. [Express approval of the donation amount]
Persuadee: Sure, tell me more about how it's used [Request more information about the charity's impact]
Persuader: A year ago, I saw kid begging on the street who look really hungry. [Share a personal anecdote to illustrate the charity's impact]
Persuader: I was about to give him some money until a representative for "Save the Children" walked ahead of me and help this kid out. [Continue the anecdote to provide more context]
Persuader: This person took them to their facility and provided food, shelter, and clothing. [Detail the charity's actions in the anecdote]
Persuader: A month later I saw the kid was healthier, happy, and cleaner. [Conclude the anecdote with positive outcome]
Persuader: I was so impress I decided to make a donation. [Express personal motivation for donating]
Persuader: Would you be interested in a donation? [Directly ask if the other person is interested in donating]
Persuadee: Wow. [Express amazement or admiration]
Persuadee: Nice story. [Compliment the story]
Persuadee: I'm very particular about who I donate to so I'd need more information [Express cautious interest and request more information]

conversation:
Persuader: Hi, I hope you are well today! [Greeting and expressing goodwill]
Persuadee: I am how are you doing? [Responding to greeting and inquiring about the other person's well-being]
Persuader: Great! [Expressing personal well-being]
Persuader: I'm getting ready to spend the day volunteering for my favorite charity! [Sharing personal plans and enthusiasm for volunteering]
Persuadee: Yes, so I think it is a good idea to donate to the childrens charity. [Agreeing and suggesting a related idea]
Persuader: Same here! [Expressing agreement]
Persuader: I am volunteering for the charity called Save the Children. [Providing specific information about the charity]
Persuader: Are you familiar with them? [Inquiring about the other person's familiarity with the charity]
Persuadee: No I am not. [Expressing lack of familiarity]
Persuadee: Can you tell me about it? [Requesting more information]
Persuader: They promote children's rights and help support kids in developing countries. [Providing information about the charity's mission]
Persuader: It takes so little money to help feed a starving child. [Emphasizing the impact of a small donation]
Persuadee: What can I do to help? [Expressing willingness to help and seeking guidance]
Persuader: I'm so glad you asked! [Expressing gratitude and readiness to provide suggestions]
Persuader: One thing you could do is agree to contribute what you make just from this one task we are doing right now. [Suggesting a specific way to contribute]
Persuadee: Ok how much do you need? [Inquiring about the amount needed]
Persuader: If you pledge to contribute the reward from this task, that will feed a starving child for a full day! [Explaining the impact of the suggested contribution]
Persuader: Isn't that amazing? [Expressing amazement at the impact]
Persuadee: That is awesome but I need the money so I can't afford to give right now. [Expressing financial constraints and inability to contribute]
Persuader: I know what you mean, I need to make money too. [Showing empathy and understanding]
Persuader: But at the same time, here we are in front of our computers, and we can work all day to make up the small amount we will contribute. [Encouraging reconsideration by highlighting the small amount needed]
Persuadee: I can't work all day. [Explaining personal limitations]
Persuadee: I have to take care of my disable family member and I really can't afford it. [Providing additional context for financial constraints]
Persuader: Oh I'm so sorry to hear that. [Expressing sympathy]
Persuader: I have problems too. [Sharing personal challenges]

conversation:
Persuader: Hello, I would like to ask you to consider making a donation to Save the Children, an international NGO committed to promoting children's rights, and providing support for children in developing countries. [Requesting a donation and introducing the cause]
Persuadee: ohh how much donation would yoy expect? [Inquiring about the expected donation amount]
Persuader: Your donation can be from $0 to all of the payment for this task. [Providing information on donation range]
Persuader: But before you decide hastily, I would like to remind you that Save the Children is one of the only charities doing what it does. [Encouraging thoughtful consideration before deciding]
Persuader: There are children out there now without access to housing, clean water, education, and many other things we often take for granted. [Highlighting the needs of children in developing countries]
Persuader: So please, consider thoughtfully whether you would be willing to make a sacrifice for the children of the world. [Urging thoughtful consideration for making a sacrifice]
Persuadee: how do i trust the organiation? [Expressing concern about the trustworthiness of the organization]
Persuader: Save the Children is a world-renowned NGO with a trusted history and background. [Reassuring about the organization's credibility]
Persuader: You can read about their successes on their website:   URL [Providing a resource for further information]
Persuader: Also, they have been given high ratings from different charity watchodgs. [Highlighting third-party endorsements]
Persuadee: okay i will check it.. by the way how much did you donate? [Expressing intent to verify and inquiring about the speaker's donation]
Persuader: I donated $2, which is the maximum payment. [Sharing personal donation amount]
Persuader: I understand that everyone cannot commit to making a serious donation, but when we think about children suffering, we have a moral imperative to act in their defense. [Emphasizing moral responsibility to act]
Persuadee: okay i will donate $1 [Committing to a specific donation amount]
Persuader: If it's not too much to ask, I would like you to consider donating perhaps more. [Requesting consideration for a higher donation]
Persuader: After all, there are children in Syria now growing up facing threats of violence everyday. [Highlighting specific urgent needs]
Persuader: Surely an additional dollar, which we might spend on a cup of coffee or a bag of chips, could more greatly aid them then us. [Comparing donation impact to everyday expenses]
Persuadee: no i am okay with this amount [Reaffirming decision on donation amount]
Persuader: OK, I will not force you to make a decision you don't want to. [Respecting the decision and not pressuring further]
Persuader: I will just ask you to consider how you would feel if your child was danger like many children are. [Appealing to empathy and personal connection]
Persuadee: actually i am not donating like this.. if i would like to donate money i will give food and clothes to the kids directly [Explaining personal donation preferences]

conversation:
Persuader: Hello. [Greeting]
Persuadee: Hello! [Greeting]
Persuader: I am supposed to ask you if you care about people being killed in Syria and things like that, I don't want to cause you any emotional discomfort by talking about suffering people. [Expressing concern about causing discomfort]
Persuader: Is that okay? [Seeking permission to discuss a sensitive topic]
Persuader: To talk about suffering people and children for a minute? [Clarifying the request to discuss suffering people and children]
Persuadee: I will have no discomfort discussing suffering people. [Reassuring that discussing suffering people is acceptable]
Persuader: I think the refugee crisis is crazy, I am not sure what I would do if I was raising my kids in Syria. [Expressing personal opinion on the refugee crisis]
Persuader: If anyone could have fun in those spots it's kids though. [Attempting to find a positive aspect in a dire situation]
Persuadee: I feel really torn about the crisis. [Expressing conflicted feelings about the crisis]
Persuadee: I don't think the weight of that burden should fall on the rest of the worlds shoulders. [Stating a belief about the responsibility of the global community]
Persuadee: At the same time as a parent I would want the best possible future for my children and I know fiercly that I would do everything in my power to make sure they were in a safe place. [Relating personal parental instincts to the situation]
Persuader: I actually didn't think of it like that. [Expressing a new perspective gained from the conversation]
Persuader: I am a parent too, it feels so foreign what they are going through. [Relating personal experience as a parent to the situation]
Persuader: This whole chat thing is supposed to get me to get you to donate to Save the Children, but now I think they got me to do it instead! [Revealing the purpose of the conversation (to solicit donations)]
Persuader: I don't know if that's really okay to do though. [Expressing uncertainty about the appropriateness of soliciting donations]
Persuadee: I always wonder how much of donations actually go where ear marked. [Expressing skepticism about the allocation of donations]
Persuadee: I see on the local level how much of donations stay local and what gets spent on things I would call "stupid". [Providing an example of local donation mismanagement]
Persuadee: I am always worried if I donate it will just go to some higer up that is living the high life. [Expressing concern about potential misuse of donations]
Persuadee: Sorry Im getting off topic. [Apologizing for deviating from the main topic]
Persuader: No, that's relevant. [Validating the relevance of the concern]
Persuader: Really relevant. [Reiterating the relevance of the concern]
Persuader: It's really easy to get cynical about life and if people really benefit from any of this. [Expressing a cynical view on the effectiveness of donations]
Persuader: I usually donate in hopes I can at least feel like I did my part. [Explaining personal motivation for donating]
Persuader: If I donated and some corrupt person took it, that's the worst karma and even worst scandal imaginable. [Expressing concern about the potential misuse of donations]
Persuader: The people who donate and people who are worrying about that are the same people. [Drawing a connection between donors and their concerns]
Persuader: You're not a horrible person it sounds like, just worried if what you do even matters. [Reassuring the other person about their intentions]
Persuadee: With that all said I do feel like any orginazation that aims to help the children I am more inclined to donate to them than most. [Expressing a preference for donating to organizations that help children]
Persuadee: My boss has a sponsored child that she sends money to every month. [Providing an example of a personal connection to child sponsorship]
Persuadee: SHe picked out a child with the same birth month as one of her kids. [Sharing a specific detail about the sponsored child]
Persuadee: I think helping children is an important thing as they are our future! [Emphasizing the importance of helping children]
Persuader: I feel like you are smart enough and definitely moral enough to be the boss. [Complimenting the other person's intelligence and morality]
Persuader: I hope you have success  in your field. [Wishing success in the other person's field]
Persuader: I don't have that great of a job or boss but I'd still  I would like to match a donation with you if you're willing to try help kids with me. [Proposing a matched donation to help children]
Persuader: I am parent and I feel like I need extra help sometimes too , but knowing that I could REALLY help them makes feel like a better parent. [Expressing personal motivation for donating as a parent]

Persuadee: What part of the world will it go to? [Requesting information about the geographical impact of the donation]
Persuader: It would go all over the world! [Stating the global reach of the organization]
Persuader: The money is used to promote childrens rights and provide food and medicine. [Providing specific uses of the donation]

Persuader: Well, lets get specific. [Proposing to discuss specific examples]

conversation:
Persuader: Have you ever heard of "Save the Children"? [Introduce the topic of "Save the Children"]
Persuader: It an agency that helps children in underdeveloped and developing countries. [Provide basic information about the organization]
Persuadee: No, I actually haven't . [Express lack of prior knowledge about the organization]
Persuadee: Do you have any more information about the organization that you could tell me? [Request more information about the organization]
Persuader: it is not sponsored or supported by any governmental agencies and it helps children abroad and within the US. [Provide additional details about the organization’s operations]
Persuader: You would be shocked at how many children live in poverty here in the United States. [Highlight the issue of child poverty in the United States]
Persuadee: I have an idea. [Acknowledge understanding of the issue]
Persuadee: Whats a more specific idea of what you do? [Request more specific information about the organization's activities]
Persuadee: How do you help? [Inquire about the methods of assistance provided by the organization]
Persuadee: Whats their overall goal? [Ask about the overall goal of the organization]
Persuader: Well, a very specific goal right is to help the children that are separated from their parents due to our current immigration problem. [Provide a specific example of the organization's current goals]
Persuader: Can you imagine someone taking your small child away from you and not knowing where they are going, who is going to be caring for them, or if you will ever be able to see them again? [Create an emotional appeal by describing a distressing scenario]
Persuader: As a mother, that thought is horrifying. [Express personal emotional connection to the issue]
Persuadee: It is horrifying, I could not even imagine. [Express empathy and agreement with the emotional appeal]
Persuadee: What do you need me to do? [Ask how they can help]
Persuader: Save the Children has committed to providing some of the care and needs for these children until they can be reunited with their parents. [Explain the organization's commitment to helping children separated from their parents]
Persuader: Would you be willing to donate your pay for this task to Save the Children so they can continue to provide care for these misplaced children? [Request a donation of the speaker's pay for the task]
Persuadee: My pay? [Seek clarification about the donation request]
Persuadee: As in my weekly paycheck? [Clarify the type of payment being referred to]
Persuadee: Or are there any other payment options, as I have bills to pay. [Inquire about alternative payment options]
Persuader: No, but you could donate part of your pay for this particular task here. [Clarify that partial payment can be donated]

conversation:
Persuader: Hello, hope your great today. [Greeting the other person and expressing hope for their well-being.]
Persuader: Have you heard of save the children. [Introducing the topic of the charity "Save the Children."]
Persuader: Hold ten? [Attempting to correct a previous typo.]
Persuadee: I'm doing well, thanks! [Responding to the greeting and expressing well-being.]
Persuadee: Likewise to you. [Reciprocating the well-wishes.]
Persuadee: I have not heard of that charity. [Stating lack of knowledge about the charity.]
Persuader: Save the children do amazing work with kind kids [Praising the charity and its work.]
Persuadee: How long has this charity been in existence? [Inquiring about the history of the charity.]
Persuader: They have been providing great services for kids for over 10 years [Providing information about the charity's history.]
Persuadee: How are they rated as a charity? [Asking about the charity's reputation.]
Persuadee: Do you have access to their overhead and admin costs breakdown vs. what they actually spend on programs? [Requesting detailed financial information about the charity.]

Persuadee: I was wondering why you were talking about "save the hold ten" vs. "save the children." [Clarifying the confusion caused by the typo.]
Persuader: Sorry, typo!! [Apologizing for the typo.]
Persuader: If you would like to donate, it can come right out if your task money today [Encouraging the other person to donate.]
Persuadee: As I recall, for save the children, they were given a bad reputation back in the '90s due to their excessive spending on administration costs vs. program expenditures. [Recalling past negative information about the charity.]
Persuadee: It was quite the scandal and they became a watchword for bad charities. [Elaborating on the charity's past scandal.]
Persuader: I believe they have gotten better the last few years! [Expressing belief that the charity has improved.]
Persuader: Would you like to donate [Asking again if the other person would like to donate.]
Persuadee: No, there are other charities that do a much better job in my opinion that I already donate to, such as Compassion International and World Vision for international children's relief, and my local food shelter. [Declining to donate and explaining preference for other charities.]
Persuadee: I can participate directly through volunteer hours and I can also actually visit the children that I help through my family's donations. [Explaining the benefits of donating to other charities.]

conversation:
Persuader: Hi, good morning! [Greeting]
Persuadee: Hello! [Greeting]

Persuadee: No, I didn't see anything. [Response to inquiry]
Persuadee: I'm a little familiar with the charity though. [Providing additional information]
Persuader: Oh, awesome! [Expressing approval]
Persuader: Well, in case you didn't know, Save the Children is a great charity that focuses on helping kids around the world. [Providing information about the charity]
Persuader: They use almost 90% of all donations directly to help children in the areas of education, safety and emergency... [Providing detailed information about donations]
Persuadee: That's good to know that almost 90 percent of all donations go directly to help children. [Expressing approval of donation usage]
Persuadee: We know it's a problem not just in the United States. [General statement about the problem]
Persuader: Yes, exactly. [Agreement]
Persuader: I'm not a fan of charities that keep a lot of their proceeds for themselves. [Expressing personal opinion]
Persuader: That's one reason I really like this one. [Providing reason for support]
Persuader: Do you think you would be willing to make a small donation to Save the Children today? [Request for donation]
Persuadee: I most likely will. [Expressing likelihood of donation]
Persuadee: I would like to read some more information, probably on their website, then donate from there. [Expressing need for more information]
Persuadee: How do they help children in other parts of the world? [Inquiry about charity's global efforts]
Persuader: Well, I know that the research team for this task can take a portion of our payment and send it directly to the Save the Children. [Providing information about donation process]
Persuader: It's quick and easy, and even thought it may not seem like a lot of money, I think that every penny counts. [Encouraging small donations]
Persuader: I believe we can contribute any portion of our payment: $0 - 0.30. [Providing specific donation options]
Persuadee: That would be alright. [Expressing acceptance]
Persuadee: Yes, I would like to donate at least one dollar to help Save the Children. [Expressing intent to donate]
Persuader: Oh great! [Expressing approval]
Persuader: I don't know if there is a maximum we can contribute, but regardless, I think your support would be really appreciated. [Providing additional information and encouragement]
Persuadee: I've heard on the news that many children around the world are with their families trying to escape wars. [Providing context about global issues]
Persuadee: I'm sure Save the Children helps them? [Inquiry about charity's involvement]
Persuader: I believe so. [Expressing belief in charity's involvement]
Persuader: In places like the middle east or southern Asia, even the smallest donation can go a long way. [Providing specific examples]
Persuadee: Yes, I agree. [Agreement]
Persuadee: It's difficult to watch the horrible things these children are going through. [Expressing empathy]
Persuadee: Our children and grandchildren are so blessed. [Expressing gratitude for personal situation]

conversation:
Persuader: Good afternoon. [Greeting]
Persuadee: Hey there how is it going? [Inquiring about well-being]
Persuader: It's going alright. [Responding to inquiry]
Persuader: I've just been reading about a charity called Save the Children. [Introducing a topic]
Persuader: Have you heard of it? [Asking for knowledge confirmation]
Persuadee: I've heard a little bit about it but don't know too much. [Providing limited knowledge]
Persuader: From what I've read, it's a nonprofit that helps children in difficult situations around the world. [Providing information]
Persuader: I was reading about their aid work in Syria and how they've helped young girls in developing countries receive schooling. [Providing additional information]
Persuadee: Oh wow! [Expressing amazement]
Persuadee: That's incredible. [Expressing admiration]
Persuadee: I wasn't aware that they did all of that. [Expressing lack of awareness]
Persuader: This morning, I was also reading about an ebola outbreak in the Congo (I think). [Sharing additional information]
Persuader: I imagine they'll help there if they aren't stretched too thin. [Speculating]
Persuadee: So save the children is a worldwide organization it sounds like! [Confirming understanding]
Persuader: It is! [Affirming]
Persuader: Do you ever donate to organizations like this? [Inquiring about donation habits]
Persuader: My brother, sister, and I replaced birthday gifts with charity donations a few years ago. [Sharing personal experience]
Persuader: It saved on clutter and felt great to give to charities. [Explaining benefits of personal experience]
Persuadee: I've given to a few charities before, but never this one. [Sharing personal experience]
Persuadee: I'm always so skeptical of charities to be honest. [Expressing skepticism]
Persuader: Same here. [Expressing agreement]
Persuader: I remember reading about some questionable charities following hurricanes in Haiti and Puerto Rico. [Providing an example]
Persuader: It's a bummer when that money gets siphoned off. [Expressing disappointment]
Persuader: I just looked up Save the Children on Charity Navigator and they give the org an 88.3 rating out of 100 including a 97 for transparency. [Providing credibility information]
Persuadee: Wow that's a really great rating! [Expressing approval]

Persuader: You Know small donations can help a lot of children and their families [Encourage small donations by highlighting their impact]
Persuadee: Really? [Express mild surprise or interest]
Persuadee: I suppose even with the economy being as hard as it is, exchange rates are still good enough to make a real impact. [Acknowledge the potential impact of donations despite economic conditions]

Persuader: Not many kids get a real shot and they all deserve one If I had a chance to change a childs life foe the better and didn't I would not be able to live with myself. [Express personal conviction about the importance of helping children]
Persuadee: That's a good point, I think a lot of the times the little things we can do that have really positive impacts kind of get lost in the shuffle. [Agree and reflect on the importance of small actions]
Persuadee: If I can ask a personal question, how did you make room in your finances to donate? [Inquire about how ER managed finances to donate]
Persuader: I did't I just gave what I thougt cas right and took the blow . [Share personal approach to donating despite financial impact]
Persuader: I thought about how these kids do without so much and realized I could do without once in order to help someone in need [Reflect on the motivation behind the donation]

Persuader: I gave what was given to me . [Share a personal principle for deciding donation amount]
Persuader: Over the next few chats I'm going to tell you the story of Bruce a child that like alot of these chidren need help but threw Save The Chidren found it. [Introduce the story of Bruce to illustrate the impact of donations]

Persuader: I want you to think about what it means to save a child thats in trouble and how by saving that child you find new hope in your own life. [Encourage reflection on the significance of saving a child]
Persuadee: I'm certainly willing to listen. [Express willingness to listen]
Persuadee: Tell me about Bruce. [Request to hear Bruce's story]
Persuader: Bruce was born to a single mother who was only 14 at the time he came into this world , the girls mother and father were ashamed of her pregnancy and kicked out of the house. [Begin narrating Bruce's background and challenges]
Persuader: The founder of save the children heard about the family and learned of Bruces story . [Introduce the founder's involvement in Bruce's story]
Persuader: He came to meet Bruce . [Describe the founder's meeting with Bruce]

Persuadee: I'm glad that Bruce was taken in, though. [Express relief that Bruce received help]
Persuadee: How did the visit go? [Inquire about the outcome of the founder's visit]

Persuader: Hey! [Greeting]

Persuadee: It sounds familiar though. [Expressing familiarity]
Persuadee: Could you tell me about it? [Requesting more information]
Persuader: Yeah, no problem! [Agreeing to provide information]
Persuader: It's a non-governmental organization that helps with children's rights. [Providing information about the organization]
Persuader: They claim to provide relief and support to kids in developing countries. [Continuing to provide information about the organization]
Persuadee: That's amazing. [Expressing amazement]
Persuadee: Do they provide legal help or support to live? [Inquiring about specific services provided by the organization]
Persuader: It looks like a bit of both! [Providing a specific answer]
Persuader: But they're down on donations. [Sharing additional information about the organization's needs]
Persuader: Curious, how willing would you be to donate to the cause? [Inquiring about willingness to donate]
Persuader: Say... if it were deducted from your task payment? [Providing a specific donation scenario]
Persuadee: I'm really passionate about children's rights no matter what background they are from. [Expressing personal values and passion]
Persuadee: When it isn't available, I think it's important to provide for them if we can. [Explaining the importance of support]
Persuadee: So, I'd be willing to donate, if I could confirm the charity was a legitimate one. [Expressing conditional willingness to donate]
Persuader: Absolutely! [Affirming the organization's credibility]
Persuader: Save the Children is quite credible, and has tons of information out there about their organization. [Providing more information to support credibility]
Persuader: They have corporate partnerships, individuals, and foundations! [Listing types of supporters to enhance credibility]
Persuadee: Oh, wow! [Expressing amazement]
Persuadee: Okay, I would definitely donate to them! [Confirming willingness to donate]
Persuader: That's so awesome to hear! [Expressing enthusiasm and appreciation]

Persuader: You can choose any amount from $0 to all of your payment. [Providing options for donation amount]
Persuadee: I'm not sure how much I would be getting from the task, but I will say $1! [Expressing uncertainty and specifying a donation amount]
Persuader: That's so awesome of you! [Expressing appreciation]
Persuader: The research team will be able to collect all donations and send it on over to Save the Children. [Explaining the donation process]
Persuader: It's a very valuable cause, and afterall, they have won up to 7 awards. [Reinforcing the value of the cause]
Persuadee: Oh, that is nice! [Expressing approval]
Persuadee: Especially now with so many children separated from their families because of the immigration disputes, I hope they can help children here even in America as well! [Expressing hope for the organization's impact]
Persuader: They absolutely have United States based programs! [Confirming the organization's local programs]
Persuader: From Avocacy, to Education, and even emergency services. [Listing types of local programs]
Persuader: I worry about those kids too, so I understand. [Expressing personal concern]
Persuader: It's a shame what's going on, I hope the problem gets rectified soon. [Expressing hope for resolution]
Persuadee: Me too. [Expressing agreement]
