conversation:
Persuader: Save the Children is an amazing charity that helps kids who are in desperate need. [Expressing admiration for the charity]
Persuader: They can help with safety, education and more. [Providing information about the charity's services]
Persuader: You can donate some of your earnings to this amazing charity. [Encouraging donation]
Persuadee: I believe in this charity, but still wonder how much of the money I donate actually helps. [Expressing belief in the charity but voicing concern]
Persuader: Every little bit makes a difference. [Reassuring the impact of donations]
Persuader: When you have people who are so poor, it's amazing what a tiny amount can do. [Emphasizing the value of small contributions]
Persuadee: I would gladly give my earnings to this charity. [Expressing willingness to donate]
Persuadee: Children hold the future of the world. [Highlighting the importance of children]
Persuader: It is really so heartbreaking when you see all of these kids not having enough to eat. [Expressing empathy for the children's plight]
Persuader: It really breaks the heart. [Reiterating emotional impact]
Persuader: They are so little. [Emphasizing the vulnerability of children]
Persuadee: I know, it always amazes me how many children are suffering around the world. [Expressing amazement at the extent of suffering]
Persuadee: It is so sad. [Expressing sadness]
Persuader: Even the little bit you donate from your earnings can go a long way to making a difference for a child. [Reiterating the impact of small donations]
Persuadee: Though MTurk they should raise quite a bit. [Speculating on the potential total donations]
Persuadee: Even though it is only .30 for this hit, with the number of people it adds up. [Noting the cumulative effect of small contributions]
Persuader: That's what happens. [Agreeing with the cumulative effect]
Persuader: Even small amounts make such a big difference when they are added up. [Reiterating the impact of small contributions]
Persuader: That's why it does make such a difference to even do small things. [Emphasizing the importance of small actions]
Persuadee: In my personal life I do pay attention to all the details and the reviews of charities. [Describing personal diligence in charity selection]
Persuadee: There are so many worthy causes that I try hard to make sure my meeker amounts go to benefit the most. [Explaining effort to maximize impact of donations]
Persuader: And Save the Children is a great charity. [Reaffirming the charity's value]
Persuader: They really do help so many kids and people. [Highlighting the charity's impact]
Persuadee: I know they are a well established charity so should have all the resources, administration wise, to get the money where it is needed most. [Expressing confidence in the charity's administration]
Persuader: I think it's wonderful that you are doing this and are going to donate. [Praising the decision to donate]

conversation:
Persuader: Good Morning! [Greeting the other person]
Persuader: How are you today? [Inquiring about the other person's well-being]
Persuadee: I am good. [Responding to the inquiry about well-being]
Persuadee: It's really nice outside where I am so I am sitting outdoors. [Sharing personal information about current activity]
Persuadee: How are you [Inquiring about the other person's well-being]
Persuader: Oh, that sounds nice. [Expressing interest in the other person's activity]
Persuader: I am well. It looks nice here today as well. [Responding to the inquiry about well-being and sharing personal information]
Persuader: What are your plans today? [Inquiring about the other person's plans for the day]
Persuadee: I have to go to work at 11:30-6. [Sharing information about work schedule]
Persuadee: But its ok, I work every Sunday. [Providing additional context about work routine]
Persuadee: So we are supposed to chat about a children's charity. [Introducing the topic of the conversation (children's charity)]
Persuadee: What are your feelings? [Inquiring about the other person's feelings on the topic]
Persuader: Yes, I was just reading about the charity myself. [Confirming familiarity with the topic]
Persuader: I was going to make a plea and ask if you would be willing to donate to Save the Children. [Expressing intention to make a plea for donation]
Persuader: It helps kids in need. [Providing information about the charity's purpose]
Persuader: I would hate to think a child would die with no food when I could ask people to help. [Expressing personal feelings to motivate the other person]
Persuader: Can you donate part of today's pay? [Requesting a donation from the other person]
Persuader: Even a bit? [Emphasizing that any amount would help]
Persuadee: It's so sad to me that anyone should go without food in our modern world. [Expressing personal feelings about the issue of hunger]
Persuadee: So I would definitely be willing to help. [Agreeing to help and expressing willingness to donate]
Persuader: Yes, I agree, it is sad. [Agreeing with the sentiment expressed by the other person]
Persuader: That is great that you can help! [Expressing appreciation for the other person's willingness to help]
Persuader: How much of today's pay can you give? [Inquiring about the specific amount the other person can donate]
Persuader: Also, please include the $ sign with your pledge. [Requesting specific format for the pledge]
Persuader: Thank you! [Expressing gratitude in advance]
Persuadee: I think the bonus of today is 2 dollars so maybe if we both give half of it? [Proposing a specific donation amount and suggesting a shared contribution]
Persuadee: That is at least something. [Expressing that any contribution is valuable]
Persuadee: I only wish that our Government would help the poor more than they do. [Expressing a wish for more government support for the poor]
Persuadee: What do you think? [Inquiring about the other person's opinion on government support]
Persuader: I would love to help as well. [Expressing willingness to help and agreeing with the sentiment]
Persuader: Can you pledge with the $ sign in your next reply. [Requesting the pledge in the specified format again]
Persuader: Also, I agree, the gov't should do more. [Agreeing with the sentiment about government support]
Persuader: And thanks for asking me too. [Expressing appreciation for being asked for an opinion]
Persuadee: So lets agree we both can give $1 of of bonus. [Proposing a final agreement on the donation amount]
Persuader: I would say that is a wonderful idea. [Expressing approval of the proposed idea]
Persuader: If you are willing to give then I will too! [Confirming willingness to match the donation]
Persuadee: Nice!!! [Expressing positive emotion about the agreement]

conversation:
Persuader: Hi! How are you doing today? [Initiate conversation and express friendly greeting]
Persuadee: Good how are you? [Respond to greeting and reciprocate inquiry]
Persuader: I'm pretty good. [Respond to inquiry and share personal state]
Persuader: Have you ever heard of the Save the Children organization? [Introduce topic of Save the Children organization]
Persuadee: I have heard of that organization. [Acknowledge familiarity with the organization]
Persuadee: I have seen a lot of commercials on TV for it. [Provide additional context about familiarity]
Persuader: I hear you. [Express understanding and agreement]
Persuader: That is when I first heard of it as well. [Share personal experience related to the topic]
Persuader: I love the fact that it is a non-government organization that promotes children's rights and helps to provide the support in those developing countries. [Express admiration for the organization’s mission]
Persuadee: Agreed. [Agree with the positive sentiment]
Persuadee: Any organization who promotes rights for those who don't have the platform to speak up is a wonderful charity. [Express support for organizations that promote rights]
Persuader: I guess now I am going to sound like the tv commercial but have you ever thought about donating to the organization? [Introduce the idea of donating to the organization]
Persuadee: I have thought about it in the past. [Share past consideration of donating]
Persuader: I understand that. [Express understanding of the consideration]
Persuader: With all the organizations out there it is hard to tell a good one and a bad one. [Acknowledge difficulty in distinguishing good organizations]
Persuader: This organization helps to children with their rights to health, education, and even safety. [Provide specific information about the organization’s efforts]
Persuadee: Yes it is hard to tell whose interests really lie in the movement they promote. [Agree with the difficulty in assessing organizations]
Persuadee: I like to research organizations first to see if the money I give is really going to the cause, or if it is wasted by high overhead costs. [Share personal approach to researching organizations]
Persuader: Yeah I totally understand that. [Express understanding of the approach]
Persuader: I know the commercials are heart wrenching...seeing all those children suffer and hurting. [Comment on the emotional impact of the commercials]
Persuader: It breaks my heart. [Express personal emotional response]
Persuadee: Absolutely. [Agree with the emotional impact]
Persuadee: It makes you look at your own children (if you have any) and think if that was them how would I cope? [Relate the situation to personal experience with children]
Persuadee: It's the reason I go to work everyday. [Share personal motivation for working]
Persuadee: To make sure that they have all that they need, and more than I ever had. [Express desire to provide for children]
Persuader: I completely understand that. [Express understanding and empathy]
Persuader: I have a little girl and it only makes me want to do more and more for her. [Share personal motivation related to own child]

conversation:
Persuader: Hi there! [Greeting the other person]
Persuader: I am looking for donations for the Save the children's Foundation? [Introducing the purpose of the conversation]

Persuadee: I would perhaps be interested can you tell me more a bout it [Expressing potential interest and requesting more information]
Persuader: It is a charity that helps hungry children in need. [Providing basic information about the charity]
Persuader: It is a international, non governmental organization that promotes children's rights, provides releif and support children in developing countries. [Expanding on the charity’s mission and scope]
Persuadee: That sounds great, What countries do they help children in? [Showing interest and asking for specific details]
Persuader: There's quite a few! It's international. [Reiterating the international scope of the charity]
Persuader: Even the smallest donation would make a difference to a child in need. [Encouraging a donation by emphasizing its impact]
Persuadee: Ok I would like to see if I can help. I love children. [Expressing willingness to help and personal motivation]
Persuader: That's great! [Expressing approval and encouragement]
Persuader: They are the future you know... [Highlighting the importance of children]
Persuader: alot of the children are in war zones and facing daily threats of violence. [Describing the dire situations faced by the children]
Persuadee: Of course nothing gets me more angry then seeing a child warrior soldier. [Expressing strong emotions about child soldiers]
Persuadee: Will we also be helping children soliders? [Seeking clarification on whether the charity helps child soldiers]
Persuader: There are no children soliders, only children that need help in some way with food, resources, emergency response, etc. [Clarifying the charity’s focus and dispelling a misconception]
Persuader: This program has saves a great deal of lives. [Emphasizing the charity’s success and impact]
Persuader: It has brought families together and gave hope to a new life. [Highlighting the positive outcomes of the charity’s work]
Persuadee: Ok thats great. [Expressing approval]
Persuadee: Do they need clothes as well? [Inquiring about other needs such as clothing]
Persuader: Yes! Alot of the proceeds go towards garments, shoes, and other things for the children. [Confirming that donations also go towards clothing and other essentials]
Persuader: Some of them are basically naked and have nothing. [Describing the dire need for clothing among the children]
Persuader: Others have no shoes. [Providing additional details about the children’s needs]
Persuader: It's really sad, but that's why there are programs out here like us to step in and provide help. [Explaining the charity’s role in addressing these needs]
Persuadee: Ok well I know it is important for them to have basic needs. [Agreeing on the importance of basic needs]
Persuadee: I hope the money donated goes directly to them and not in the pockets of those running the organization. [Expressing concern about the proper use of donations]

conversation:
Persuader: Hi! [Greeting the other person]

Persuader: Just some ver basic info, Save the Children is an international non-governmental organization that promotes children's rights, provides relief and helps support children in developing countries. [Providing basic information about Save the Children]
Persuadee: Are they a non profit organization? [Seeking clarification about the organization's status]
Persuader: Yes they are! [Confirming the organization's non-profit status]
Persuader: They work 100% on donated funds. [Explaining the funding source of the organization]

conversation:
Persuader: Good afternoon/evening [Greeting the other participant]
Persuadee: Hello [Responding to the greeting]
Persuader: Looks like there might be a bonus coming at the end of this HIT, have you got any plans for the money? [Introducing the topic of a potential bonus and inquiring about plans for the money]
Persuadee: Nope, what do you recommend? [Expressing lack of plans and seeking recommendations]
Persuader: I read a lot about the Save the Children charity before I came in here. [Sharing information about a charity]
Persuader: I hope that more people will donate a portion of their income. [Expressing hope for more donations]
Persuader: Even small amounts will definitely help [Emphasizing the impact of small donations]
Persuadee: What's Save the Children all about? [Requesting more information about the charity]
Persuader: They provide relief and support to children in developing nations, especially the millions of kids who are at risk in Syria. [Providing details about the charity's mission]
Persuader: They are a charity we can trust, so I think we all should do our part to help the less fortunate [Expressing trust in the charity and encouraging participation]
Persuadee: Do they provide for the millions of hungry kids here in the USA? [Questioning the charity's focus on international aid]
Persuader: They concentrate on developing countries, but, personally, I think that there is just as great a need abroad as there is at home [Clarifying the charity's focus and sharing a personal opinion]
Persuadee: Yeah, i think an American charity should focus on America too [Expressing a preference for domestic charity focus]
Persuader: That's true, but we're all in this together, as they say. [Acknowledging the point and promoting a global perspective]
Persuader: People far away need help just as much as people close to us. [Reiterating the need for global assistance]
Persuader: You could even take the money that you want to give to charity and split it in half among American and international relief agencies [Suggesting a compromise for donations]
Persuadee: That would work best for me. [Agreeing with the suggestion]
Persuadee: That way i know where my money is going. [Expressing a desire for transparency in donations]
Persuadee: Is there a minimum to donate? [Inquiring about donation minimums]
Persuader: No, there is no minimum that I've ever heard of. [Informing that there is no minimum donation]
Persuader: They know that any small amount can help. [Reiterating the value of small donations]
Persuadee: That's great! [Expressing approval]
Persuadee: Is there a website where i can donate? [Asking for the donation website]
Persuader: I'm glad to hear it! [Expressing gladness at the interest]
Persuader: Save the Children do have a website at  URL [Providing the website URL]
Persuader: You can learn more about them there, but there's an easier way to donate [Mentioning an easier way to donate]
Persuadee: What is the easier way? [Requesting details about the easier way]
Persuader: The researchers behind this HIT are gathering up donations so that they can give the money to the charity all at once. [Explaining the researchers' donation collection method]

conversation:
Persuader: Hello [Greeting the other person.]
Persuadee: Hi. [Responding to the greeting.]
Persuader: Are you willing to donate to Save the Children? [Inquiring about willingness to donate.]
Persuadee: Yes. [Expressing willingness to donate.]
Persuadee: I would very much like to donate. [Reaffirming the intention to donate.]
Persuader: how much are you willing to donate? [Asking for the amount of donation.]
Persuadee: Well, I don't have much money right now. [Explaining financial limitations.]
Persuadee: All I can afford is $5.00. [Stating the amount they can afford to donate.]
Persuader: I think that is an excellent amount and would benefit Save the Children. [Validating the donation amount and encouraging the donor.]
Persuader: For example,millions of Syrian children have grown up facing the daily threat of violence. [Providing context about the cause.]
Persuader: In the first two months of 2018 alone, 1,000 children were reportedly killed or injured in intensifying violence. [Highlighting the urgency and severity of the situation.]
Persuader: Your donation will make an impact to better childrens' live around the world. [Emphasizing the impact of the donation.]
Persuadee: That's so horrible. [Expressing empathy and concern.]
Persuadee: I wish I could give more. [Expressing a desire to contribute more.]
Persuadee: I sponsor a poor child in India every month for $40. [Sharing personal involvement in charitable activities.]
Persuadee: I wish I could help all the children in the world. [Expressing a broader wish to help.]
Persuader: I would like to personally thank you for that. [Expressing gratitude for the donor's contributions.]
Persuader: It is very thoughtful to donate to causes that benefit disadvantaged children. [Commending the donor's thoughtfulness.]
Persuader: Your donation means a lot to that child in India [Reiterating the importance of the donor's contributions.]
Persuadee: It is the least I can do for him. [Minimizing their own contributions.]
Persuadee: Most people take for granted what they have in their lives, while there are so many thousands who do not even have the basic necessities. [Reflecting on societal disparities.]
Persuadee: Imagine not have clean water to drink. [Highlighting a basic necessity that is often taken for granted.]
Persuader: I cannot even begin to imagine that and clean water should be a basic right to every child on this planet. [Agreeing and emphasizing the importance of clean water.]
Persuadee: I agree. [Agreeing with the previous statement.]
Persuadee: There is so much wasted in the world. [Commenting on global wastefulness.]
Persuadee: I know it is possible for everyone to have enough food and water. [Expressing belief in the possibility of global sufficiency.]
Persuadee: If only the governments and politicians of the world would stop fighting and actually work toward that goal. [Criticizing political inaction and conflict.]
Persuader: Yes I agree. [Agreeing with the criticism.]
Persuader: That is why I donate what I can to organizations like Save the Children. [Explaining personal motivation for donating.]
Persuader: As you may know, Save the Children is an international non-governmental organization that promotes children's rights, provides relief and helps support children in developing countries. [Providing information about Save the Children.]
Persuader: Are there any organizations that you can reccomend? [Asking for recommendations of other organizations.]
Persuadee: I sponsor through World Vision. [Sharing their preferred organization.]
Persuadee: I like them because they are very transparent about where the money is going. [Explaining why they like the organization.]
Persuadee: You can see photos and videos of your sponsor child and his or her community. [Describing the transparency and engagement of the organization.]
Persuadee: And they let you know what type of progress is occuring both with your child and the community in general. [Detailing the progress updates provided by the organization.]

conversation:
Persuader: Hello. [Greeting the other person]
Persuader: Have you ever heard of the organization Save the Children? [Introducing the topic of Save the Children]
Persuadee: I haven't [Responding to the question and indicating lack of prior knowledge]
Persuader: They are an amazing organization with a national and an international presence. [Providing information about the organization]
Persuader: Would you like to know more about what they do? [Offering to provide more information]
Persuadee: I think I'm okay. [Declining the offer for more information]
Persuadee: No need to share more information [Reinforcing the decision to not receive more information]
Persuader: I understand and I do not want to take up too much of your time. [Expressing understanding and respect for the other person's time]
Persuader: But please know that this organization ehlps children on every continent but Antartica. [Providing additional information about the organization's reach]
Persuadee: Why not Antartica? [Asking a follow-up question out of curiosity]
Persuader: There just isn't the population to warrant it. [Explaining why the organization does not operate in Antarctica]
Persuader: The climate is not sustainable for human life and children do not reside there. [Providing further explanation about the climate and population]
Persuader: But in the other countries they provide emergency response, global advocacy,  literacy, and health education. [Listing the types of services the organization provides]
Persuadee: Well that's disappointing. [Expressing disappointment]
Persuadee: What country receives the most aid? [Asking for more specific information about aid distribution]
Persuader: It is spread out by need but rest assured that their charity ranges from Kentucky all the way to Kenya. [Explaining how aid is distributed based on need]
Persuader: Also, 86% of all expenditures go to program services so everyone that donates knows that their money is being used for a good cause rather than misappropriated. [Providing information about the efficiency of the charity's expenditures]
Persuadee: Okay sounds interesting. [Expressing interest in the information provided]
Persuadee: How do people donate to the charity? [Inquiring about how to donate]
Persuader: You can visit their website or I can assist you with donating today. [Providing options for how to donate]
Persuader: Can I ask if you have ever donated to a charity before? [Asking about the other person's past donation history]
Persuadee: Yes I have in the past, but not recently [Sharing past donation behavior]
Persuader: Glad to hear it. [Expressing positive reinforcement]
Persuader: Charity is very important. [Stating the importance of charity]
Persuader: Is this a charity you believe to be doing a good thing based on the information I have provided? [Asking for the other person's opinion on the charity]
Persuadee: Sounds like a good mission, but I probably won't be able to donate [Expressing a positive opinion but declining to donate]

conversation:
Persuader: Hello how are you today? [Greeting and initiating conversation]
Persuadee: I'm good. [Responding to greeting]
Persuadee: How are you? [Inquiring about the other person's well-being]
Persuader: I am doing great! [Responding positively to inquiry]
Persuader: I am here to let you know about this amazing international foundation called Save the Children that promotes children's rights, provides relief and helps support them in developing countries. [Introducing the purpose of the conversation and providing information about the charity]
Persuadee: Please tell me more. [Expressing interest and requesting more information]
Persuader: These children are being used in horrific ways, the food and supplies that are supposed to be going to them are being stolen and we are trying to gather money to ensure the supplies get to these children who really need these supplies and help. With a donation today, not only will we be able to ensure the supply lines safely reach villages, but doctors will also go and help the children with medical care they desperately need. [Providing detailed information about the charity's mission and the issues it addresses]
Persuader: All I ask is that you donate a portion of your task payment to this charity to help the children. [Making a direct request for a donation]
Persuadee: How do I know this charity is legit? [Expressing skepticism and seeking validation of the charity's legitimacy]
Persuader: You are free to look up any information you like at  URL [Providing a resource for verification]
Persuadee: How much of the donations goto the children and the effort? [Inquiring about the allocation of donations]
Persuader: 100% of your donation will go directly to Save the Children. [Assuring that all donations go directly to the charity]
Persuader: Just think of it this way, instead of getting your morning coffee, or that bag of chips at lunch, you could donate $2 today and help ensure that 3 children get the care they need and food in their stomachs. [Encouraging donation by comparing it to small daily expenses]
Persuadee: Does 100% go to the effort directly or does any of the monies go to employees like the director of the charity ect? [Seeking clarification on the use of donations and potential administrative costs]
Persuader: The research team will collect all donations and send it all directly to Save the children. [Clarifying the process of donation collection and allocation]
Persuader: So it will go to pay for the flights to get the team over there, medicine, food, everything needed to help these children [Explaining the specific uses of the donations]
Persuadee: What roughly is the percentage that goes to the running of the charity and helping the children directly? [Requesting a specific percentage breakdown of donation allocation]
Persuader: Like I said earlier, 100% of your donation goes directly to helping these children. [Reiterating that 100% of the donation goes to helping children]
Persuader: Look, already in 2018 alone, 1,000 children have been reportedly killed or injured in intensifying violence. [Providing a statistic to emphasize the urgency of the situation]
Persuader: They need your help. [Appealing to the listener's empathy]
Persuader: They need your donation more than you do honestly. [Emphasizing the importance of the donation]
Persuader: What is $2 to you when that money can literally save lives over there? [Encouraging donation by highlighting its impact]
Persuadee: There are many scams out there that take more to profit then to actually help the kids. [Expressing concern about potential scams]

conversation:
Persuader: Hello there, how are you? [Initiate conversation and establish rapport]
Persuadee: Hi [Respond to greeting]
Persuader: How much do you know about Save the Children? [Inquire about EE's knowledge of Save the Children]
Persuadee: I know that it is a charity. [Provide basic information about Save the Children]
Persuadee: I think I have seen some commercials for it in my lifetime. [Share personal experience related to Save the Children]
Persuader: Were you aware that Save the Children assists both children in the U.S. as well as foreign countries? [Provide additional information about Save the Children's scope]
Persuadee: No. [Express lack of awareness]
Persuadee: I figured they just tried to help children in under developed countries. [Share assumption about Save the Children's focus]
Persuadee: That's great that they help people in the U.S. as well! [Express approval of Save the Children's broader scope]
Persuadee: I think it's important to help children from our country and also others. [Share personal belief about the importance of helping children]
Persuader: Yes, not only do we help out with literacy and school related causes, but also with feeding, shelter, and disaster relief for children all over the world. [Provide detailed information about Save the Children's activities]
Persuadee: That's wonderful! [Express approval]
Persuadee: Are you a top rated charity? [Inquire about the charity's rating]
Persuadee: How much goes to administrative costs? [Inquire about administrative costs]
Persuader: We are a top rated charity, and have been around for nearly 100 years! [Confirm high rating and provide historical context]
Persuader: Nearly 90% of our funds go straight to children, with the remainder going to fundraising costs and only 5% for admin costs. [Provide detailed breakdown of fund allocation]
Persuadee: Wow!  That's really great! [Express approval and surprise]
Persuadee: I've seen companies go to 70% and I can't help but judge them for it. [Share personal judgment about other companies' fund allocation]
Persuadee: I think this is a fair percentage to have. [Express opinion on fair percentage for administrative costs]
Persuader: We try our best to keep the children first, and have done so in aiding millions of children over the years. [Reiterate commitment to prioritizing children]
Persuadee: I think that's great! [Express approval]
Persuadee: What country is in the most need right now? [Inquire about countries in most need]

conversation:
Persuader: Hello, have you heard of Save The Children? [Initiate conversation and introduce the topic of Save The Children]
Persuadee: I think so, it sounds familiar. [Express familiarity with the topic]
Persuadee: it is a nonprofit charity if i recall. [Confirm understanding of the organization as a nonprofit charity]
Persuadee: What exactly do they do? [Seek more detailed information about the organization's activities]
Persuader: Save The Children helps kids from around the world by taking contributions from generous patrons. Kids from countries that have been stricken by poverty, violence, and other blights. [Provide detailed information about the organization's mission and activities]
Persuadee: What countries has the charity worked in recently? [Inquire about specific countries where the charity has recently worked]
Persuader: Well, we have programs set up in 120 countries in total right now. [Provide information about the scope of the organization's programs]
Persuader: Some of our most recent campaigns involve Myanmar - in Rohingya where parents and their children have been forced to flee because of violence to surrounding countries. In the largest refugee camp stationed in Bangladesh, there are an estimated 915,000 children and adults taking shelter. [Give specific examples of recent campaigns and their impact]
Persuadee: Wow that sounds like a really robust program. [Express admiration for the organization's efforts]
Persuadee: How long has Save the Children been around? [Inquire about the history of the organization]
Persuader: It was founded in 1919, on April 15th in London - UK. [Provide historical information about the organization's founding]
Persuadee: Do you work for Save the Children or do you just volunteer for the charity? [Inquire about the speaker's relationship with the organization]
Persuader: I do not work for them, I work on behalf of them. [Clarify the nature of their involvement with the organization]
Persuader: That is why I'm talking to you today. [Explain the purpose of the current conversation]
Persuader: These children need help, and could use it from generous people like you. [Emphasize the need for help and appeal for support]
Persuader: A meal, an education, an opportunity like everyone else, that is all these kids want. [Highlight the basic needs of the children the organization helps]
Persuader: Even one cent will add up to help a child in need, but if you wish you may donate up to 2 dollars. [Explain the donation process and suggest donation amounts]
Persuader: For every cent you donate it will come directly from your task payment. [Clarify how donations will be deducted]
Persuadee: I love to help charities that serve a good cause and I would love to donate but I do have one question. [Express willingness to donate but indicate a need for more information]
Persuadee: What is the portion of donations that goes to children versus the portion that goes to administration or other expenses [Inquire about the allocation of donations between direct aid and administrative costs]
Persuader: Sure, absolutely. In 2017, 86% went to Program services - or services that directly help aid these children. 9% went towards fundraising efforts, and 5% went towards our Management & other general costs. In 2018 we anticipate similar numbers. [Provide detailed information about the allocation of donations]
Persuadee: That's pretty impressive! [Express admiration for the organization's financial transparency]
Persuadee: Not too many charities can claim such a strong commitment to the cause. [Compare the organization favorably to other charities]
Persuader: We do it for them, not for ourselves. [Reaffirm the organization's commitment to its cause]
Persuader: And we hope our numbers reflect that amount of love and effort that goes toward what we do. [Express hope that the organization's financial transparency reflects its dedication]
Persuadee: I'd be willing to donate $1 to Save the Children. [Commit to making a donation]

conversation:
Persuader: Donate to Save the Children, please. [Requesting donation]
Persuader: Think about those poor kids. [Appealing to empathy]
Persuadee: Well tell me a little bit more about the charity. [Requesting more information]
Persuader: It's really all in the name. [Deflecting request for information]
Persuader: You have a moral responsibility. [Appealing to moral responsibility]
Persuadee: A lot of charities are just a name and they don't do what they promise. [Expressing skepticism]
Persuadee: How do I know my money will go where it supposed to? [Seeking assurance about fund allocation]
Persuader: They're a world-famous trustworthy charity. [Providing assurance about trustworthiness]
Persuader: If they were fraudulent or misallocating funds, surely there'd have been a scandal. [Providing rationale for trustworthiness]
Persuadee: Ok. [Indicating tentative agreement]
Persuadee: So why do they deserve my money as opposed to other charities like St Judes or the Red Cross> [Questioning the uniqueness of the charity]
Persuader: Of course you can donate to other charities. [Conceding the possibility of donating to other charities]
Persuader: It's not necessarily a zero-sum game. [Clarifying that donations are not mutually exclusive]
Persuader: I can tell you, however, that Save the Children is, in a way, more immediate in helping people (as opposed to fighting disease like St Jude's) and delivers services similar to the Red Cross, but directed toward children. [Explaining the unique impact of the charity]
Persuader: So, please: think of the children! [Reiterating appeal to empathy]
Persuadee: Do they help kids in the US? [Inquiring about the charity's scope]
Persuadee: I like to help people that are close to home. [Expressing preference for local impact]
Persuader: Their assistance is directed toward children in developing countries, where, unlike most of the US, children are totally deprived of opportunity and basic services. [Clarifying the charity's focus on developing countries]
Persuader: Though you, being the generous person you are, like helping those at home, is there a reason not to help children abroad? [Challenging the preference for local impact]
Persuadee: I don't mind helping those abroad. [Expressing willingness to help abroad]
Persuadee: But there are a lot kids here in the US who deal with poverty. [Highlighting local needs]
Persuadee: So it's not that I don't care about the children elsewhere, just want to help those at home first. [Clarifying intention to prioritize local help]

conversation:
Persuader: Have you heard of the charity Save the Children? [To inquire if the other person is aware of the charity Save the Children.]
Persuadee: Yes I have, but I don't know a lot about it. [To acknowledge awareness but express limited knowledge about the charity.]
Persuader: They promote children's rights, provides relief, and helps support children in developing countries. [To provide information about the charity's mission and activities.]
Persuadee: That sounds like a very nice cause. [To express a positive opinion about the charity's cause.]
Persuader: Yes, it\'s a great cause. [To agree and reinforce the positive opinion about the charity.]
Persuader: And the charity is highly rated with many positive rewards. [To add credibility by mentioning the charity's high ratings and positive rewards.]
Persuader: Including an "A" rating from the American Institute of Philanthropy. [To provide specific information about the charity's rating from a reputable organization.]
Persuadee: That's awesome! [To express admiration and approval.]
Persuadee: Do you know when the charity began? [To inquire about the history of the charity.]
Persuader: It was founded way back on April 15, 1919! [To provide information about the founding date of the charity.]
Persuader: A charity with that kind of history shows that it has made an amazing impact. [To emphasize the charity's long history and its impact.]
Persuader: Just last year they helped a total of 155 million children! [To provide a recent statistic to highlight the charity's effectiveness.]
Persuadee: That is very impressive. [To express being impressed by the charity's achievements.]
Persuadee: Do you know on average how much money the charity makes per year? [To inquire about the charity's average annual revenue.]
Persuader: The total operating revenue was $807,412 in 2017, and 9 out of every 10  dollars they make goes straight into the programs and services to help children and families in need. [To provide detailed financial information about the charity's revenue and expenditure.]
Persuadee: That is awesome. [To express admiration for the charity's financial transparency.]
Persuader: I know I was surprised by those numbers. [To share a personal reaction to the financial information.]
Persuader: A lot of widely known charities aren't as open and honest about where their finances go, but you can easily find Save the Children's financial reports online. [To highlight the charity's transparency compared to other organizations.]
Persuader: That's important to me in a charity. [To express personal values regarding charity transparency.]
Persuadee: Yes, definitely. [To agree with the importance of transparency.]
Persuadee: Unfortunately some "charities" are just scams that do not donate to a worthy cause at all. [To express concern about fraudulent charities.]
Persuader: That's the truth. [To agree with the concern about fraudulent charities.]
Persuader: That's why it's so important to do research before donating. [To emphasize the importance of researching before donating.]
Persuader: Save the Children even breaks down where exactly your money goes on their website. [To provide additional information about the charity's financial transparency.]
Persuader: For example, 34% of the money donated goes to health & nutrition services and programs, 21% to education, 11% to emergencies, 11% to HIV/AIDs, etc. [To give specific details about how donations are allocated.]
Persuader: It is fully listed on the site with an easy to read graphic. [To mention the availability of an easy-to-read graphic on the charity's website.]
Persuader: Super helpful. [To express that the information is helpful.]
Persuadee: That's very helpful. [To agree that the information is helpful.]
Persuadee: It is best to be transparent when running a charity like that, especially when the charity brings in a large amount of money. [To emphasize the importance of transparency for large charities.]
Persuadee: That way nobody can question anything. [To state that transparency prevents questioning of the charity's integrity.]
Persuader: Oh yeah. [To express agreement.]
Persuader: When I first heard about these super well known organizations only actually using about 5% of their proceeds for their services I was shocked. [To share a personal reaction to learning about other charities' low usage of proceeds for services.]
Persuader: Save the Children uses a total of 86% of proceeds for their services and programs! [To highlight Save the Children's high percentage of proceeds used for services.]
Persuader: The rest goes to "fundraising, management, and general" as the website says. [To provide additional details about the allocation of the remaining proceeds.]

conversation:
Persuader: Hello. [Greeting the other participant.]
Persuader: Would you like to donate a portion of your reward to a charity called Save the Children? [Requesting a donation to a specific charity.]
Persuadee: I think I would be willing to donate a portion. [Expressing willingness to donate.]
Persuader: Excellent! [Expressing approval and encouragement.]
Persuader: Would you like to know more about the charity first? [Offering additional information about the charity.]
Persuadee: Yes, that was going to be my next question. [Confirming interest in more information.]
Persuader: Save the Children promotes children's rights, and helps children from developing countries. [Providing information about the charity's mission.]
Persuadee: What types of children's rights? [Requesting specific details about the charity's focus.]
Persuader: Your donation would help ensure children's rights to health, education, and safety. [Clarifying the specific rights the charity supports.]
Persuader: Many of these children live in developing or war-torn areas where these basic necessities are hard to come by. [Providing context about the children's living conditions.]
Persuadee: What type of people or who manages this fund? [Inquiring about the management of the charity.]
Persuader: Save the Children has excellent credentials and is managed by a board of commercial CEOs and business leaders without any government or religious affiliation. [Providing information about the charity's management and credentials.]
Persuadee: Does Save the Children help children in the United States? [Asking if the charity helps children in the United States.]
Persuader: Yes! [Confirming that the charity helps children in the United States.]
Persuader: Since 1932, Save the Children has been on the ground providing support to the most isolated and underserved children in rural America. [Providing historical context about the charity's work in the US.]
Persuader: Many of these children don't have the same opportunities as others and live in very difficult conditions. [Describing the conditions of the children the charity helps in the US.]
Persuadee: That is awesome. [Expressing approval of the charity's work.]
Persuadee: I work hard to help children as well. [Sharing personal involvement in helping children.]
Persuader: That's great! [Expressing approval and encouragement.]
Persuader: It is a worthwhile cause and every penny has a significant impact on these children's lives. [Emphasizing the impact of donations.]
Persuader: Even a small donation can have a large impact in impoverished areas. [Highlighting the significance of even small donations.]
Persuadee: I am curious why you chose the words "rural America"? [Questioning the choice of words used by the speaker.]
Persuader: Of course. [Expressing willingness to explain.]
